gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: This data was gathered from ship launched Expendable Bathythermogaph (XBT) probes. The XBT probe is dropped off a moving ship and falls under its own weight. The probe has a a thermistor in its nose whose electrical resistance changes as the water temperature changes. This is sensed as a changing resistance which is transmitted to the digital recorder on the ship. Using an algorithm the resistance is converted to a water temperature. The speed of fall of the probe is known and from the elapsed time the depth is calculated. The time of the XBT drop is recorded from the computers clock. The position of the drop is obtained from the ship's satellite navigation or GPS. Position is manually entered by the ship's operator.

mcp:name.gco:CharacterString: temperature of the water column by expendable bathythermograph (XBT)

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
The RAN METOC use standard UNESCO, IOC/IODE documented procedures for quality control of temperature profile data. Temperature data undergoes scientific quality control procedures. Each temperature profile is visually inspected for possible faults and checked for profile-to-profile consistency with nearest neighbours and also compared with climatological average temperature profiles from the World Ocean Atlas. Temperature/depth pairs are flagged with quality control flags which are stored with the data.
Starting in 2009 the RAN METOC XBT data was quality controlled using the CSIRO developed MQUEST system. MQUEST is a Matlab-based system for quality evaluation of subsurface temperature profile data (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/Mquest/MQuESTmanual.pdf ). Prior to 2009 RAN METOC used the 'Marine QC' Ver3.0 a semi-automatic system, developed by RAN-METOC, for the quality control.
The meaning of quality control flags are documented in Table 1 of CSIRO Marine Laboratories Report No. 221 (1994) titled "Quality Control Cookbook for XBT data" (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/cookbook/csiro.htm ). The flags correspond to a set of 'data quality classes' (0-9) which have the same meaning as in Section 2 of IOC Manuals and guides No. 22 GTSPP REAL-TIME QUALITY CONTROL MANUAL (see http://www.meds-sdmm.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/alphapro/gtspp/qcmans/mg22/guide22_e.htm ).
After QC has completed the data is output from MQUEST system into MEDS-ASCII GTSPP file format see http://www.nodc.noaa.gov/GTSPP/document/datafmt/medsfmt.html for details about this data format.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Port Kembla Offshore Wave Data (WAVEPOK) - Deployment No. 4 14-JUN-1984 to 27-MAY-1988

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Port Kembla at latitude -34.466944, longitude 151.016667 and water depth 76 metres. The data is gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). IMOS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)
Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN). AODN is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)

* OEH and MHL accept no responsibility for any loss or damage that may occur through the use of, or reliance on, the data by the recipient.

mcp:parameterDescription.gco:CharacterString: sea surface wave mean wave height
Root mean square displacement of waves on the sea surface
Average height of the waves which comprise the highest one tenth of waves at the sea surface

mean crest period of waves at the sea surface taken from measurements of period between successive crests
Average zero crossing period of the highest one third of waves at the sea surface

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to download netCDF data file

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Prior to a six to eight month deployment, the operation of a Waverider buoy is tested on the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory Waverider buoy calibration rig to ensure it meets the manufacturers operational specifications.
Wave data are transmitted from the Waverider buoy to a shore station where it is processed to produce wave data statistics. The recorded bursts of wave data (normally 34 minutes long starting on the hour) are digitised at 0.5-second intervals (or 0.78-second intervals for a Directional Waverider buoy) and the data are conditioned to remove any erroneous data points. The data are then analysed using two procedures: zero crossing analysis and spectral analysis.
The wave data is routinely quality controlled (usually twice per week) using a wave data quality control program developed by Manly Hydraulics Laboratory. The wave data statistics are examined and raw data and spectral plots are viewed by an experience operator to check for any anomalies. Wave statistics from adjacent Waverider stations are also compared to assist in the identification of any "out of range" values. Erroneous wave data records are removed and good quality data is flagged as "Quality Controlled" in the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory wave database.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: RAN Sea Surface Temperature Data - HMAS DIAMANTINA CruiseID: SST_09DM_1976_05 From: 1976-10-01 To: 1976-10-05

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains quality controlled Sea Surface Temperature (SST) observations measured by dipping a mercury in glass thermometer into an insulated bucket of collected sea water. The dataset contains 19 SST measurements obtained by HMAS Diamantina. Positional data was recorded at an accuracy of one tenth of a degree, and temperature was collected at an precision of one tenth of a degree Celsius. Position and temperature were then recorded and typed onto logs with the date and time in GMT, which were submitted to the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre (AODC) for processing.

It is the temperature of sea water near the surface (including the part under sea-ice, if any), and not the skin temperature, whose standard name is surface_temperature. gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: The data from this dataset were submitted as typed logs, which were entered by hand into a spreadsheet. The data then underwent checks for typographical errors or transcription errors, before positional data was converted to a uniform format (+/-DD.MM or +/-DDD.MM). Data was plotted in GIS software to check for positional error (for example, data points not following ship track, or on land), followed by a gross range check on temperature data to ensure that no erroneous temperature data was passed outside the range of 0-35 degrees Celsius.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS MELVILLE ProjectID: HI453MEL_M From: 2008-07-01 To: 2008-09-01

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 322 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise HI453MEL_M from HMAS MELVILLE.
The CTD was manufactured by Applied Microsystems Limited and is the "Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the MVP200_CTD. This CTD is fitted with a 4 electrode platinized conductivity cell, thermistor temperature sensor and a semiconductor strain gauge pressure sensor.
The CTD sensors are calibrated at the manufacturer Applied Microsystems Limited on a 12-18 month schedule. The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated against 'Hart' temperature standards. The pressure sensor is calibrated using 'Budenburg Deadweight' standards. The conductivity sensor is calibrated using 'Hart' temperature standards and seawater samples of known conductivity.
The CTD sensors are mounted to a fish-shape probe. The probe is controlled by an electric winch (MVP200 type). For downcasts the fish is allowed to free-fall (winch is in 'free-wheel' mode) under its own weight at about 2-3 ms-1 and then is winched back. Data is recorded in downcast and usually in upcast direction at a sampling rate of 25 Hz. The downcast data is of higher quality because sensors encounter undisturbed seawater that flows through the nose of the fish. On the upcast the fish is flipped around (tail first) and the sensors in the nose encounter disturbed flow from the fish tail.
This type of CTD is prone to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' caused by a mismatch between the response times of the temperature and conductivity sensor. Data undergoes a salinity de-spiking routine to correct for this. See the history metadata for further details on the salinity de-spiking process.
Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to CTD data in netCDF
Data quality notes

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Initial Processing
Incoming data undergoes gross range checks and removal of any corrupted or unrealistic data. Some CTD data is subject to a pressure offset error generally less than 1 decibar. A pressure offset error occurs when the pressure sensor does not read 0 dbar in air. In cases where the pressure offset error was observed before the CTD cast the pressure readings have been corrected for the offset which is stored in the global netCDF attribute named 'CTD_pressure_offset'.
Salinity on the PSS-78 scale is computed from conductivity, temperature and pressure using the UNESCO (1983) algorithm with temperature corrected from the ITS-90 scale to the ITS-68 scale used by the algorithm.
For this CTD model the response time (time constant) of the temperature sensor (100 ms) is slower than the conductivity cell (25ms). This leads to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' in the salinity data. Spiking is caused by the fact that calculated salinity is a function of conductivity, temperature and pressure [S=f(C,T,z)]. The temperature response lags the conductivity response resulting an error in the calculation of salinity. This is evident as noticeable spikes in the salinity profiles especially at depths where temperature is rapidly changing e.g in the ocean thermocline. The spiking was reduced reduced by applying a 2.5 sample time shift (0.1 s) to the temperature values and using the shifted temperature value in the re-computation of the salinity. An array of raw pressure, temperature and de-spiked salinity is then passed to the next processing stage.
The raw CTD data contains a non-monotonic sequence of pressures due to up/down motion of ship/winch. A sequence of unique monotonic pressures up to the maximum value is extracted and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure levels with the corresponding interpolated temperature and salinity. Finally the interpolated files are converted to a set of netCDF files ready for QC.
Quality Control
Quality control (QC) involves viewing location of the data on a map, visual inspection of each profile of temperature and salinity and comparison with nearest neighbours and climatology. CTD profiles are checked for any density inversions i.e. density decreasing with depth by computing sigma-t density. A density inversion may indicate unrealistic salinity and/or temperature values. QC flags are applied to indicate whether data is good, suspect, bad or not tested. QC flags may apply at the 'whole profile' level or individual pressure levels.
CTD cast positions and times undergo a land and ship speed check. Casts with position on land or unrealistic speed between casts are flagged as failed position or time. Temperature and salinity profiles are then visually compared against a 3 standard deviation envelope from the CSIRO-CARS (2009) atlas. Profiles or segments of profiles with data outside the envelope are flagged as doubtful or failed. Profiles are also checked for consistency or doubtful features by comparing with previous/next casts (buddies) and also by comparison with historical CTD casts taken in the same area and season.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
The RAN METOC use standard UNESCO, IOC/IODE documented procedures for quality control of temperature profile data. Temperature data undergoes scientific quality control procedures. Each temperature profile is visually inspected for possible faults and checked for profile-to-profile consistency with nearest neighbours and also compared with climatological average temperature profiles from the World Ocean Atlas. Temperature/depth pairs are flagged with quality control flags which are stored with the data.
Starting in 2009 the RAN METOC XBT data was quality controlled using the CSIRO developed MQUEST system. MQUEST is a Matlab-based system for quality evaluation of subsurface temperature profile data (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/Mquest/MQuESTmanual.pdf ). Prior to 2009 RAN METOC used the 'Marine QC' Ver3.0 a semi-automatic system, developed by RAN-METOC, for the quality control.
The meaning of quality control flags are documented in Table 1 of CSIRO Marine Laboratories Report No. 221 (1994) titled "Quality Control Cookbook for XBT data" (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/cookbook/csiro.htm ). The flags correspond to a set of 'data quality classes' (0-9) which have the same meaning as in Section 2 of IOC Manuals and guides No. 22 GTSPP REAL-TIME QUALITY CONTROL MANUAL (see http://www.meds-sdmm.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/alphapro/gtspp/qcmans/mg22/guide22_e.htm ).
After QC has completed the data is output from MQUEST system into MEDS-ASCII GTSPP file format see http://www.nodc.noaa.gov/GTSPP/document/datafmt/medsfmt.html for details about this data format.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Byron Bay Offshore Wave Data (WAVEBYB) - Deployment No. 18 14-MAY-1992 to 18-JUN-1993

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Byron Bay at latitude -28.698611, longitude 153.746111 and water depth 73 metres. Data from October 1976 to October 1999 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In October 1999 the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to download netCDF data file

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Prior to a six to eight month deployment, the operation of a Waverider buoy is tested on the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory Waverider buoy calibration rig to ensure it meets the manufacturers operational specifications.
Wave data are transmitted from the Waverider buoy to a shore station where it is processed to produce wave data statistics. The recorded bursts of wave data (normally 34 minutes long starting on the hour) are digitised at 0.5-second intervals (or 0.78-second intervals for a Directional Waverider buoy) and the data are conditioned to remove any erroneous data points. The data are then analysed using two procedures: zero crossing analysis and spectral analysis.
The wave data is routinely quality controlled (usually twice per week) using a wave data quality control program developed by Manly Hydraulics Laboratory. The wave data statistics are examined and raw data and spectral plots are viewed by an experience operator to check for any anomalies. Wave statistics from adjacent Waverider stations are also compared to assist in the identification of any "out of range" values. Erroneous wave data records are removed and good quality data is flagged as "Quality Controlled" in the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory wave database.

mcp:parameterDescription.gco:CharacterString: Sea surface temperature is usually abbreviated as SST. It is the temperature of sea water near the surface (including the part under sea-ice, if any), and not the skin temperature, whose standard name is surface_temperature. For the temperature of sea water at a particular depth or layer, a data variable of sea_water_temperature with a vertical coordinate axis should be used.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains observations of marine bioluminescence. Bioluminescence is the emission of light by living organisms. It can be stimulated by the movements of water (waves), organisms (fish) or ships. The organisms which emit light occur over a wide range of taxa such as bacteria, protozoa, fungi, crustaceans, insects, fish, squid, jellyfish and benthic plants. For each bioluminescence observation there are coded descriptions of stimulus, color, kind, duration and extent. Time is recorded in UTC and position is obtained from the ship's navigation instruments.
The source data also includes information on oceanographic and meteorological conditions at the time of the observation. This includes cloud cover, present weather, water depth, sea surface temperature, wind speed and direction, wave period and height, swell direction, swell period and swell height. For further information on data collection procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/defence/documents/HI_manual.pdf.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS MERMAID ProjectID: SRATD-0030MER_M From: 2011-11-25 To: 2011-12-01

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 2 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise SRATD-0030MER_M from HMAS MERMAID.
The CTD was manufactured by Applied Microsystems Limited and is the "Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the MVP200_CTD. This CTD is fitted with a 4 electrode platinized conductivity cell, thermistor temperature sensor and a semiconductor strain gauge pressure sensor.
The CTD sensors are calibrated at the manufacturer Applied Microsystems Limited on a 12-18 month schedule. The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated against 'Hart' temperature standards. The pressure sensor is calibrated using 'Budenburg Deadweight' standards. The conductivity sensor is calibrated using 'Hart' temperature standards and seawater samples of known conductivity.
The CTD sensors are mounted to a fish-shape probe. The probe is controlled by an electric winch (MVP200 type). For downcasts the fish is allowed to free-fall (winch is in 'free-wheel' mode) under its own weight at about 2-3 ms-1 and then is winched back. Data is recorded in downcast and usually in upcast direction at a sampling rate of 25 Hz. The downcast data is of higher quality because sensors encounter undisturbed seawater that flows through the nose of the fish. On the upcast the fish is flipped around (tail first) and the sensors in the nose encounter disturbed flow from the fish tail.
This type of CTD is prone to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' caused by a mismatch between the response times of the temperature and conductivity sensor. Data undergoes a salinity de-spiking routine to correct for this. See the history metadata for further details on the salinity de-spiking process.
Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to CTD data in netCDF
Data quality notes

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Initial Processing
Incoming data undergoes gross range checks and removal of any corrupted or unrealistic data. Some CTD data is subject to a pressure offset error generally less than 1 decibar. A pressure offset error occurs when the pressure sensor does not read 0 dbar in air. In cases where the pressure offset error was observed before the CTD cast the pressure readings have been corrected for the offset which is stored in the global netCDF attribute named 'CTD_pressure_offset'.
Salinity on the PSS-78 scale is computed from conductivity, temperature and pressure using the UNESCO (1983) algorithm with temperature corrected from the ITS-90 scale to the ITS-68 scale used by the algorithm.
For this CTD model the response time (time constant) of the temperature sensor (100 ms) is slower than the conductivity cell (25ms). This leads to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' in the salinity data. Spiking is caused by the fact that calculated salinity is a function of conductivity, temperature and pressure [S=f(C,T,z)]. The temperature response lags the conductivity response resulting an error in the calculation of salinity. This is evident as noticeable spikes in the salinity profiles especially at depths where temperature is rapidly changing e.g in the ocean thermocline. The spiking was reduced reduced by applying a 2.5 sample time shift (0.1 s) to the temperature values and using the shifted temperature value in the re-computation of the salinity. An array of raw pressure, temperature and de-spiked salinity is then passed to the next processing stage.
The raw CTD data contains a non-monotonic sequence of pressures due to up/down motion of ship/winch. A sequence of unique monotonic pressures up to the maximum value is extracted and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure levels with the corresponding interpolated temperature and salinity. Finally the interpolated files are converted to a set of netCDF files ready for QC.
Quality Control
Quality control (QC) involves viewing location of the data on a map, visual inspection of each profile of temperature and salinity and comparison with nearest neighbours and climatology. CTD profiles are checked for any density inversions i.e. density decreasing with depth by computing sigma-t density. A density inversion may indicate unrealistic salinity and/or temperature values. QC flags are applied to indicate whether data is good, suspect, bad or not tested. QC flags may apply at the 'whole profile' level or individual pressure levels.
CTD cast positions and times undergo a land and ship speed check. Casts with position on land or unrealistic speed between casts are flagged as failed position or time. Temperature and salinity profiles are then visually compared against a 3 standard deviation envelope from the CSIRO-CARS (2009) atlas. Profiles or segments of profiles with data outside the envelope are flagged as doubtful or failed. Profiles are also checked for consistency or doubtful features by comparing with previous/next casts (buddies) and also by comparison with historical CTD casts taken in the same area and season.

mcp:parameterDescription.gco:CharacterString: Sea surface temperature is usually abbreviated as SST. It is the temperature of sea water near the surface (including the part under sea-ice, if any), and not the skin temperature, whose standard name is surface_temperature. For the temperature of sea water at a particular depth or layer, a data variable of sea_water_temperature with a vertical coordinate axis should be used.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains observations of secchi disc depth. The secchi disc is a white disc which is lowered into the water, and the depth at which the disc is no longer visible is recorded. This gives a measure of the water clarity (turbidity). Also observed is the water color using the Forel-Ule scale. The recovery of the disc is stopped at 1 metre below the surface and water color is estimated by comparing to a colour card with standard Forel-Ule colors. Time is recorded in UTC and position is obtained from the ship's navigation instruments.
The source data also includes information on oceanographic and meteorological conditions at the time of the observation. This includes cloud cover, present weather, water depth, sea surface temperature, wind speed and direction, wave period and height, swell direction, swell period and swell height. For further information on data collection procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/defence/documents/HI_manual.pdf.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains quality controlled Sea Surface Temperature (SST) observations measured by dipping a mercury in glass thermometer into an insulated bucket of collected sea water. The dataset contains 354 SST measurements obtained by HMAS Melbourne. Positional data was recorded at an accuracy of one tenth of a degree, and temperature was collected at an precision of one tenth of a degree Celsius. Position and temperature were then recorded and typed onto logs with the date and time in GMT, which were submitted to the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre (AODC) for processing.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: The data from this dataset were submitted as typed logs, which were entered by hand into a spreadsheet. The data then underwent checks for typographical errors or transcription errors, before positional data was converted to a uniform format (+/-DD.MM or +/-DDD.MM). Data was plotted in GIS software to check for positional error (for example, data points not following ship track, or on land), followed by a gross range check on temperature data to ensure that no erroneous temperature data was passed outside the range of 0-35 degrees Celsius.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: This data was gathered from ship launched Expendable Bathythermogaph (XBT) probes. The XBT probe is dropped off a moving ship and falls under its own weight. The probe has a a thermistor in its nose whose electrical resistance changes as the water temperature changes. This is sensed as a changing resistance which is transmitted to the digital recorder on the ship. Using an algorithm the resistance is converted to a water temperature. The speed of fall of the probe is known and from the elapsed time the depth is calculated. The time of the XBT drop is recorded from the computers clock. The position of the drop is obtained from the ship's satellite navigation or GPS. Position is manually entered by the ship's operator.

mcp:name.gco:CharacterString: temperature of the water column by expendable bathythermograph (XBT)

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: The RAN METOC use standard UNESCO, IOC/IODE documented procedures for quality control. RAN METOC use the Marine QC Ver3.0 a semi-automatic system, developed in-house, for the quality control of RAN thermal data. The temperature profile (XBT) data undergoes scientific quality control procedures. Each temperature profile is visually inspected for possible faults and checked for profile-to-profile consistency with nearest neighbours and also compared with climatological average temperature profiles from the World Ocean Atlas. Temperature/depth pairs are flagged with quality control flags which are stored with data. The meaning of quality control flags are documented in the CSIRO Marine Laboratories Report No. 221 (1994) titled "Quality Control Cookbook for expendable bathythermograph data". For further information on data processing and quality control procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/documents/marineqc.pdf.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Byron Bay Offshore Wave Data (WAVEBYB) - Deployment No. 29 11-DEC-2007 to 20-AUG-2009

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Byron Bay at latitude -28.822500, longitude 153.665556 and water depth 62 metres. Data from October 1976 to October 1999 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In October 1999 the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). IMOS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)
Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN). AODN is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to download netCDF data file

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Prior to a six to eight month deployment, the operation of a Waverider buoy is tested on the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory Waverider buoy calibration rig to ensure it meets the manufacturers operational specifications.
Wave data are transmitted from the Waverider buoy to a shore station where it is processed to produce wave data statistics. The recorded bursts of wave data (normally 34 minutes long starting on the hour) are digitised at 0.5-second intervals (or 0.78-second intervals for a Directional Waverider buoy) and the data are conditioned to remove any erroneous data points. The data are then analysed using two procedures: zero crossing analysis and spectral analysis.
The wave data is routinely quality controlled (usually twice per week) using a wave data quality control program developed by Manly Hydraulics Laboratory. The wave data statistics are examined and raw data and spectral plots are viewed by an experience operator to check for any anomalies. Wave statistics from adjacent Waverider stations are also compared to assist in the identification of any "out of range" values. Erroneous wave data records are removed and good quality data is flagged as "Quality Controlled" in the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory wave database.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS MELVILLE ProjectID: SRATA-0135MEL_M From: 2008-01-17 To: 2008-01-20

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 86 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise SRATA-0135MEL_M from HMAS MELVILLE.
The CTD was manufactured by Applied Microsystems Limited and is the "Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the MVP200_CTD. This CTD is fitted with a 4 electrode platinized conductivity cell, thermistor temperature sensor and a semiconductor strain gauge pressure sensor.
The CTD sensors are calibrated at the manufacturer Applied Microsystems Limited on a 12-18 month schedule. The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated against 'Hart' temperature standards. The pressure sensor is calibrated using 'Budenburg Deadweight' standards. The conductivity sensor is calibrated using 'Hart' temperature standards and seawater samples of known conductivity.
The CTD sensors are mounted to a fish-shape probe. The probe is controlled by an electric winch (MVP200 type). For downcasts the fish is allowed to free-fall (winch is in 'free-wheel' mode) under its own weight at about 2-3 ms-1 and then is winched back. Data is recorded in downcast and usually in upcast direction at a sampling rate of 25 Hz. The downcast data is of higher quality because sensors encounter undisturbed seawater that flows through the nose of the fish. On the upcast the fish is flipped around (tail first) and the sensors in the nose encounter disturbed flow from the fish tail.
This type of CTD is prone to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' caused by a mismatch between the response times of the temperature and conductivity sensor. Data undergoes a salinity de-spiking routine to correct for this. See the history metadata for further details on the salinity de-spiking process.
Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to CTD data in netCDF
Data quality notes

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Initial Processing
Incoming data undergoes gross range checks and removal of any corrupted or unrealistic data. Some CTD data is subject to a pressure offset error generally less than 1 decibar. A pressure offset error occurs when the pressure sensor does not read 0 dbar in air. In cases where the pressure offset error was observed before the CTD cast the pressure readings have been corrected for the offset which is stored in the global netCDF attribute named 'CTD_pressure_offset'.
Salinity on the PSS-78 scale is computed from conductivity, temperature and pressure using the UNESCO (1983) algorithm with temperature corrected from the ITS-90 scale to the ITS-68 scale used by the algorithm.
For this CTD model the response time (time constant) of the temperature sensor (100 ms) is slower than the conductivity cell (25ms). This leads to a phenomenon called 'salinity spiking' in the salinity data. Spiking is caused by the fact that calculated salinity is a function of conductivity, temperature and pressure [S=f(C,T,z)]. The temperature response lags the conductivity response resulting an error in the calculation of salinity. This is evident as noticeable spikes in the salinity profiles especially at depths where temperature is rapidly changing e.g in the ocean thermocline. The spiking was reduced reduced by applying a 2.5 sample time shift (0.1 s) to the temperature values and using the shifted temperature value in the re-computation of the salinity. An array of raw pressure, temperature and de-spiked salinity is then passed to the next processing stage.
The raw CTD data contains a non-monotonic sequence of pressures due to up/down motion of ship/winch. A sequence of unique monotonic pressures up to the maximum value is extracted and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure levels with the corresponding interpolated temperature and salinity. Finally the interpolated files are converted to a set of netCDF files ready for QC.
Quality Control
Quality control (QC) involves viewing location of the data on a map, visual inspection of each profile of temperature and salinity and comparison with nearest neighbours and climatology. CTD profiles are checked for any density inversions i.e. density decreasing with depth by computing sigma-t density. A density inversion may indicate unrealistic salinity and/or temperature values. QC flags are applied to indicate whether data is good, suspect, bad or not tested. QC flags may apply at the 'whole profile' level or individual pressure levels.
CTD cast positions and times undergo a land and ship speed check. Casts with position on land or unrealistic speed between casts are flagged as failed position or time. Temperature and salinity profiles are then visually compared against a 3 standard deviation envelope from the CSIRO-CARS (2009) atlas. Profiles or segments of profiles with data outside the envelope are flagged as doubtful or failed. Profiles are also checked for consistency or doubtful features by comparing with previous/next casts (buddies) and also by comparison with historical CTD casts taken in the same area and season.

The XBT probe is dropped off a moving ship and falls under its own weight. The probe has a a thermistor in its nose whose electrical resistance changes as the water temperature changes. This is sensed as a changing resistance which is transmitted to the digital recorder on the ship. Using an algorithm the resistance is converted to a water temperature. The speed of fall of the probe is known and from the elapsed time the depth is calculated. The time of the XBT drop is recorded from the computers clock. The position of the drop is obtained from the ship's satellite navigation or GPS. Position is manually entered by the ship's operator.

mcp:name.gco:CharacterString: temperature of the water column by expendable bathythermograph (XBT)

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: BODC Parameter Usage Vocabulary (P011)
BODC Data Storage Units (P061)

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and METOC Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
The RAN METOC use standard UNESCO, IOC/IODE documented procedures for quality control of temperature profile data. Temperature data undergoes scientific quality control procedures. Each temperature profile is visually inspected for possible faults and checked for profile-to-profile consistency with nearest neighbours and also compared with climatological average temperature profiles from the World Ocean Atlas. Temperature/depth pairs are flagged with quality control flags which are stored with the data.
Starting in 2009 the RAN METOC XBT data was quality controlled using the CSIRO developed MQUEST system. MQUEST is a Matlab-based system for quality evaluation of subsurface temperature profile data (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/Mquest/MQuESTmanual.pdf ). Prior to 2009 RAN METOC used the 'Marine QC' Ver3.0 a semi-automatic system, developed by RAN-METOC, for the quality control.
The meaning of quality control flags are documented in Table 1 of CSIRO Marine Laboratories Report No. 221 (1994) titled "Quality Control Cookbook for XBT data" (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/cookbook/csiro.htm ). The flags correspond to a set of 'data quality classes' (0-9) which have the same meaning as in Section 2 of IOC Manuals and guides No. 22 GTSPP REAL-TIME QUALITY CONTROL MANUAL (see http://www.meds-sdmm.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/alphapro/gtspp/qcmans/mg22/guide22_e.htm ).
After QC has completed the data is output from MQUEST system into MEDS-ASCII GTSPP file format see http://www.nodc.noaa.gov/GTSPP/document/datafmt/medsfmt.html for details about this data format.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Sydney Offshore Wave Data (WAVESYD) - Deployment No. 5 22-MAR-1994 to 25-FEB-1995

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Sydney at latitude -33.771389, longitude 151.417500 and water depth 85 metres. The data is gathered using the Directional Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Prior to a six to eight month deployment, the operation of a Waverider buoy is tested on the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory Waverider buoy calibration rig to ensure it meets the manufacturers operational specifications.
Wave data are transmitted from the Waverider buoy to a shore station where it is processed to produce wave data statistics. The recorded bursts of wave data (normally 34 minutes long starting on the hour) are digitised at 0.5-second intervals (or 0.78-second intervals for a Directional Waverider buoy) and the data are conditioned to remove any erroneous data points. The data are then analysed using two procedures: zero crossing analysis and spectral analysis.
The wave data is routinely quality controlled (usually twice per week) using a wave data quality control program developed by Manly Hydraulics Laboratory. The wave data statistics are examined and raw data and spectral plots are viewed by an experience operator to check for any anomalies. Wave statistics from adjacent Waverider stations are also compared to assist in the identification of any "out of range" values. Erroneous wave data records are removed and good quality data is flagged as "Quality Controlled" in the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory wave database.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS LEEUWIN ProjectID: HI488LEE_H From: 2011-02-12 To: 2011-02-21

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 2 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise HI488LEE_H from HMAS LEEUWIN.
The CTD was manufactured by Falmouth Scientific and is the "2-inch Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the HS_CTD. This CTD is fitted within an inductive type conductivity cell, a platinum thermometer and silicon pressure sensor.
The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated on the ITS-90 temperature scale against a master CTD using a controlled temperature bath. The pressure sensor is calibrated using a Druck Pressure Calibrator. The conductivity sensor is calibrated in a temperature controlled bath against seawater samples of known conductivity.
The HS_CTD is lowered and raised by a hand winch sampling at a rate of 1.83 Hz. Data files were recorded in the downcast and upcast direction but most data is from downcasts due to higher quality. Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals and converted to netCDF format files. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to CTD data in netCDF
Data quality notes

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Initial Processing
Incoming data undergoes gross range checks and removal of any corrupted or unrealistic data. Some CTD data is subject to a pressure offset error generally less than 1 decibar. A pressure offset error occurs when the pressure sensor does not read 0 dbar in air. In cases where the pressure offset error was observed before the CTD cast the pressure readings have been corrected for the offset which is stored in the global netCDF attribute named 'CTD_pressure_offset'. In some cases there is a separate recording for the downcast and upcast. The downcast data were selected as priority for better quality data. In rarer cases only an upcast was available so it is used by default.
Salinity on the PSS-78 scale is computed from conductivity, temperature and pressure using the UNESCO (1983) algorithm with temperature corrected from the ITS-90 scale to the ITS-68 scale used by the algorithm.
The raw CTD data contains a non-monotonic sequence of pressures due to up/down motion of ship/winch. A sequence of unique monotonic pressures up to the maximum value is extracted and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure levels with the corresponding interpolated temperature and salinity. Finally the interpolated files are converted to a set of netCDF files ready for QC.
Quality Control
Quality control (QC) involves viewing location of the data on a map, visual inspection of each profile of temperature and salinity and comparison with nearest neighbours and climatology. CTD profiles are checked for any density inversions i.e. density decreasing with depth by computing sigma-t density. A density inversion may indicate unrealistic salinity and/or temperature values. QC flags are applied to indicate whether data is good, suspect, bad or not tested. QC flags may apply at the 'whole profile' level or individual pressure levels.
CTD cast positions and times undergo a land and ship speed check. Casts with position on land or unrealistic speed between casts are flagged as failed position or time. Temperature and salinity profiles are then visually compared against a 3 standard deviation envelope from the CSIRO-CARS (2009) atlas. Profiles or segments of profiles with data outside the envelope are flagged as doubtful or failed. Profiles are also checked for consistency or doubtful features by comparing with previous/next casts (buddies) and also by comparison with historical CTD casts taken in the same area and season.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Batemans Bay Offshore Wave Data (WAVEBAB) - Deployment No. 4 30-JUN-1988 to 07-FEB-1989

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Batemans Bay at latitude -35.703333, longitude 150.363056 and water depth 84 metres. Data from May 1986 to February 2001 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In February 2001, the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains sea surface temperature (SST) data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Batemans Bay approximately six kilometres from the coastline. The SST is measured by a thermistor mounted in the buoy hull approximately 400 mm below the water surface. The thermistor has a resolution of 0.05 Celsius and an accuracy of 0.2 Celsius. The SST measurements are transmitted to a shore station where it is stored on a PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains observations of marine bioluminescence. Bioluminescence is the emission of light by living organisms. It can be stimulated by the movements of water (waves), organisms (fish) or ships. The organisms which emit light occur over a wide range of taxa such as bacteria, protozoa, fungi, crustaceans, insects, fish, squid, jellyfish and benthic plants. For each bioluminescence observation there are coded descriptions of stimulus, color, kind, duration and extent. Time is recorded in UTC and position is obtained from the ship's navigation instruments.
The source data also includes information on oceanographic and meteorological conditions at the time of the observation. This includes cloud cover, present weather, water depth, sea surface temperature, wind speed and direction, wave period and height, swell direction, swell period and swell height. For further information on data collection procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/defence/documents/HI_manual.pdf.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains observations of secchi disc depth. The secchi disc is a white disc which is lowered into the water, and the depth at which the disc is no longer visible is recorded. This gives a measure of the water clarity (turbidity). Also observed is the water color using the Forel-Ule scale. The recovery of the disc is stopped at 1 metre below the surface and water color is estimated by comparing to a colour card with standard Forel-Ule colors. Time is recorded in UTC and position is obtained from the ship's navigation instruments.
The source data also includes information on oceanographic and meteorological conditions at the time of the observation. This includes cloud cover, present weather, water depth, sea surface temperature, wind speed and direction, wave period and height, swell direction, swell period and swell height. For further information on data collection procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/defence/documents/HI_manual.pdf.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains coded descriptions of seabed sediment samples. Seabed samples are collected using grabs, anchors, dredges or corers and analysed for their physical composition. Sediment descriptions such as colour and texture, as well as presence of other features, such as fossils or shells are documented. The sediment description uses codes from the publication 'Hydrographic Office Chart 5011 Symbols and abbreviations used on Admiralty Charts (INT1)" in the section 'Nature of the Seabed'. Time is recorded in UTC and position is obtained from the ship¿s navigation instruments.
The source data also includes information on oceanographic and meteorological conditions at the time of the observation. This includes cloud cover, present weather, water depth, sea surface temperature, wind speed and direction, wave period and height, swell direction, swell period and swell height. For further information on data collection procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/defence/documents/HI_manual.pdf.

mcp:name.gco:CharacterString: Grain-size size class lower limit (Wentworth scale) by visual estimation

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains quality controlled Sea Surface Temperature (SST) observations measured by dipping a mercury in glass thermometer into an insulated bucket of collected sea water. The dataset contains 134 SST measurements obtained by HMAS Brisbane. Positional data was recorded at an accuracy of one tenth of a degree, and temperature was collected at an precision of one tenth of a degree Celsius. Position and temperature were then recorded and typed onto logs with the date and time in GMT, which were submitted to the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre (AODC) for processing.

It is the temperature of sea water near the surface (including the part under sea-ice, if any), and not the skin temperature, whose standard name is surface_temperature. For the temperature of sea water at a particular depth or layer, a data variable of sea_water_temperature with a vertical coordinate axis should be used.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: The data from this dataset were submitted as typed logs, which were entered by hand into a spreadsheet. The data then underwent checks for typographical errors or transcription errors, before positional data was converted to a uniform format (+/-DD.MM or +/-DDD.MM). Data was plotted in GIS software to check for positional error (for example, data points not following ship track, or on land), followed by a gross range check on temperature data to ensure that no erroneous temperature data was passed outside the range of 0-35 degrees Celsius.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: This data was gathered from ship launched Expendable Bathythermogaph (XBT) probes. The XBT probe is dropped off a moving ship and falls under its own weight. The probe has a a thermistor in its nose whose electrical resistance changes as the water temperature changes. This is sensed as a changing resistance which is transmitted to the digital recorder on the ship. Using an algorithm the resistance is converted to a water temperature. The speed of fall of the probe is known and from the elapsed time the depth is calculated. The time of the XBT drop is recorded from the computers clock. The position of the drop is obtained from the ship's satellite navigation or GPS. Position is manually entered by the ship's operator.

mcp:name.gco:CharacterString: temperature of the water column by expendable bathythermograph (XBT)

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
The RAN METOC use standard UNESCO, IOC/IODE documented procedures for quality control of temperature profile data. Temperature data undergoes scientific quality control procedures. Each temperature profile is visually inspected for possible faults and checked for profile-to-profile consistency with nearest neighbours and also compared with climatological average temperature profiles from the World Ocean Atlas. Temperature/depth pairs are flagged with quality control flags which are stored with the data.
Starting in 2009 the RAN METOC XBT data was quality controlled using the CSIRO developed MQUEST system. MQUEST is a Matlab-based system for quality evaluation of subsurface temperature profile data (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/Mquest/MQuESTmanual.pdf ). Prior to 2009 RAN METOC used the 'Marine QC' Ver3.0 a semi-automatic system, developed by RAN-METOC, for the quality control.
The meaning of quality control flags are documented in Table 1 of CSIRO Marine Laboratories Report No. 221 (1994) titled "Quality Control Cookbook for XBT data" (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/cookbook/csiro.htm ). The flags correspond to a set of 'data quality classes' (0-9) which have the same meaning as in Section 2 of IOC Manuals and guides No. 22 GTSPP REAL-TIME QUALITY CONTROL MANUAL (see http://www.meds-sdmm.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/alphapro/gtspp/qcmans/mg22/guide22_e.htm ).
After QC has completed the data is output from MQUEST system into MEDS-ASCII GTSPP file format see http://www.nodc.noaa.gov/GTSPP/document/datafmt/medsfmt.html for details about this data format.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Batemans Bay Offshore Wave Data (WAVEBAB) - Deployment No. 12 29-APR-1998 to 30-JUL-2004

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Batemans Bay at latitude -35.706667, longitude 150.344722 and water depth 73 metres. Data from May 1986 to February 2001 was gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics.
In February 2001, the station was upgraded with a Datawell Directional Waverider buoy. The Directional Waverider buoy utilises a heave-pitch-roll sensor, two fixed X and Y accelerometers and a three axis fluxgate compass to measure both vertical and horizontal motion. An on-board processor converts the buoy motion to three orthogonal (vertical, north-south, east-west) translation signals that are transmitted to the shore station. The directional spectrum is also routinely transmitted to the receiving station for further processing. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). IMOS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)
Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN). AODN is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString:
Recipients of this ocean wave data will be subject to the following conditions:
* The data is provided to the recipient on an 'as-is' basis. OEH and MHL provide no guarantees as to the accuracy or reliability of the data collected and provided to IMOS.
* OEH and MHL accept no responsibility for any loss or damage that may occur through the use of, or reliance on, the data by the recipient.
* OEH is clearly acknowledged as the provider of the data whenever used or published.
* The recipient of the data undertakes not to distribute the data to third parties nor use it to gain commercial benefit unless prior approval in writing is obtained from OEH / MHL.

mcp:parameterDescription.gco:CharacterString: sea surface wave mean wave height
Root mean square displacement of waves on the sea surface
Average height of the waves which comprise the highest one tenth of waves at the sea surface
Maximum wave height in a recorded burst of raw data at the sea surface
mean crest period of waves at the sea surface taken from measurements of period between successive crests
Average zero crossing period of the highest one third of waves at the sea surface
Root mean square amplitude from wave spectral analysis (the square root of the zeroth spectral moment M0). Not to be confused with the sea_surface_wave_root_mean_square_wave_height
Wave Period at the second largest peak of the sea surface wave energy spectrum
Zeroth spectral moment (M0) of the sea surface wave energy spectrum
mean height of the waves which comprise the highest one third of waves at the sea surface
sea surface wave period at the peak of the energy spectrum
sea suface wave direction (coming from) at the spectral maximum of the wave energy spectrum
sea surface wave zero upcrossing period or the mean wave period

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to download netCDF data file

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Prior to a six to eight month deployment, the operation of a Waverider buoy is tested on the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory Waverider buoy calibration rig to ensure it meets the manufacturers operational specifications.
Wave data are transmitted from the Waverider buoy to a shore station where it is processed to produce wave data statistics. The recorded bursts of wave data (normally 34 minutes long starting on the hour) are digitised at 0.5-second intervals (or 0.78-second intervals for a Directional Waverider buoy) and the data are conditioned to remove any erroneous data points. The data are then analysed using two procedures: zero crossing analysis and spectral analysis.
The wave data is routinely quality controlled (usually twice per week) using a wave data quality control program developed by Manly Hydraulics Laboratory. The wave data statistics are examined and raw data and spectral plots are viewed by an experience operator to check for any anomalies. Wave statistics from adjacent Waverider stations are also compared to assist in the identification of any "out of range" values. Erroneous wave data records are removed and good quality data is flagged as "Quality Controlled" in the Manly Hydraulics Laboratory wave database.

MQUEST is a Matlab-based system for quality evaluation of subsurface temperature profile data (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/Mquest/MQuESTmanual.pdf ). The meaning of quality control flags are documented in Table 1 of CSIRO Marine Laboratories Report No. 221 (1994) titled "Quality Control Cookbook for XBT data" (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/cookbook/csiro.htm ). The flags correspond to a set of 'data quality classes' (0-9) which have the same meaning as in Section 2 of IOC Manuals and guides No. 22 GTSPP REAL-TIME QUALITY CONTROL MANUAL (see http://www.meds-sdmm.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/alphapro/gtspp/qcmans/mg22/guide22_e.htm ).
After QC has completed the data is output from MQUEST system into MEDS-ASCII GTSPP file format see http://www.nodc.noaa.gov/GTSPP/document/datafmt/medsfmt.html for details about this data format.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains coded descriptions of seabed sediment samples. Seabed samples are collected using grabs, anchors, dredges or corers and analysed for their physical composition. Sediment descriptions such as colour and texture, as well as presence of other features, such as fossils or shells are documented. The sediment description uses codes from the publication 'Hydrographic Office Chart 5011 Symbols and abbreviations used on Admiralty Charts (INT1)" in the section 'Nature of the Seabed'. Time is recorded in UTC and position is obtained from the ship¿s navigation instruments.
The source data also includes information on oceanographic and meteorological conditions at the time of the observation. This includes cloud cover, present weather, water depth, sea surface temperature, wind speed and direction, wave period and height, swell direction, swell period and swell height. For further information on data collection procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/defence/documents/HI_manual.pdf.

mcp:name.gco:CharacterString: Grain-size size class lower limit (Wentworth scale) by visual estimation

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains observations of marine bioluminescence. Bioluminescence is the emission of light by living organisms. It can be stimulated by the movements of water (waves), organisms (fish) or ships. The organisms which emit light occur over a wide range of taxa such as bacteria, protozoa, fungi, crustaceans, insects, fish, squid, jellyfish and benthic plants. For each bioluminescence observation there are coded descriptions of stimulus, color, kind, duration and extent. Time is recorded in UTC and position is obtained from the ship's navigation instruments.
The source data also includes information on oceanographic and meteorological conditions at the time of the observation. This includes cloud cover, present weather, water depth, sea surface temperature, wind speed and direction, wave period and height, swell direction, swell period and swell height. For further information on data collection procedures see the document http://www.metoc.gov.au/defence/documents/HI_manual.pdf.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: RAN CTD Profile Data - HMAS LEEUWIN ProjectID: HI444LEE_H From: 2007-07-30 To: 2007-08-10

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset contains quality controlled vertical profiles of pressure, temperature and salinity measured by a Conductivity, Temperature and Depth (CTD) probe. The dataset contains 7 CTD profiles (casts) obtained during RAN Hydrographic Survey cruise HI444LEE_H from HMAS LEEUWIN.
The CTD was manufactured by Falmouth Scientific and is the "2-inch Micro CTD" model. This CTD type is referred to operationally as the HS_CTD. This CTD is fitted within an inductive type conductivity cell, a platinum thermometer and silicon pressure sensor.
The CTD temperature sensor is calibrated on the ITS-90 temperature scale against a master CTD using a controlled temperature bath. The pressure sensor is calibrated using a Druck Pressure Calibrator. The conductivity sensor is calibrated in a temperature controlled bath against seawater samples of known conductivity.
The HS_CTD is lowered and raised by a hand winch sampling at a rate of 1.83 Hz. Data files were recorded in the downcast and upcast direction but most data is from downcasts due to higher quality. Raw CTD pressure data is not always monotonic due to transient up/down motion of winch/ship. Raw pressure data is subsetted to give a monotonic (increasing) sequence and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure intervals and converted to netCDF format files. Data is then flagged with quality control flags after visual inspection and comparison to average climatology and historical CTD casts.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Part of the long term ocean monitoring program.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Marine Metadata Interoperability (MMI) Ontology Registry and Repository

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Royal Australian Navy Hydrography and Metoc Branch

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Garden Island, Wylde Street, Potts Point

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Point of truth URL of this metadata record
Link to CTD data in netCDF
Data quality notes

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Initial Processing
Incoming data undergoes gross range checks and removal of any corrupted or unrealistic data. Some CTD data is subject to a pressure offset error generally less than 1 decibar. A pressure offset error occurs when the pressure sensor does not read 0 dbar in air. In cases where the pressure offset error was observed before the CTD cast the pressure readings have been corrected for the offset which is stored in the global netCDF attribute named 'CTD_pressure_offset'. In some cases there is a separate recording for the downcast and upcast. The downcast data were selected as priority for better quality data. In rarer cases only an upcast was available so it is used by default.
Salinity on the PSS-78 scale is computed from conductivity, temperature and pressure using the UNESCO (1983) algorithm with temperature corrected from the ITS-90 scale to the ITS-68 scale used by the algorithm.
The raw CTD data contains a non-monotonic sequence of pressures due to up/down motion of ship/winch. A sequence of unique monotonic pressures up to the maximum value is extracted and then linearly interpolated to 1 decibar pressure levels with the corresponding interpolated temperature and salinity. Finally the interpolated files are converted to a set of netCDF files ready for QC.
Quality Control
Quality control (QC) involves viewing location of the data on a map, visual inspection of each profile of temperature and salinity and comparison with nearest neighbours and climatology. CTD profiles are checked for any density inversions i.e. density decreasing with depth by computing sigma-t density. A density inversion may indicate unrealistic salinity and/or temperature values. QC flags are applied to indicate whether data is good, suspect, bad or not tested. QC flags may apply at the 'whole profile' level or individual pressure levels.
CTD cast positions and times undergo a land and ship speed check. Casts with position on land or unrealistic speed between casts are flagged as failed position or time. Temperature and salinity profiles are then visually compared against a 3 standard deviation envelope from the CSIRO-CARS (2009) atlas. Profiles or segments of profiles with data outside the envelope are flagged as doubtful or failed. Profiles are also checked for consistency or doubtful features by comparing with previous/next casts (buddies) and also by comparison with historical CTD casts taken in the same area and season.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains quality controlled Sea Surface Temperature (SST) observations measured by dipping a mercury in glass thermometer into an insulated bucket of collected sea water. The dataset contains 24 SST measurements obtained by HMAS Vendetta. Positional data was recorded at an accuracy of one tenth of a degree, and temperature was collected at an precision of one tenth of a degree Celsius. Position and temperature were then recorded and typed onto logs with the date and time in GMT, which were submitted to the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre (AODC) for processing.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: The data from this dataset were submitted as typed logs, which were entered by hand into a spreadsheet. The data then underwent checks for typographical errors or transcription errors, before positional data was converted to a uniform format (+/-DD.MM or +/-DDD.MM). Data was plotted in GIS software to check for positional error (for example, data points not following ship track, or on land), followed by a gross range check on temperature data to ensure that no erroneous temperature data was passed outside the range of 0-35 degrees Celsius.

mcp:attributionConstraints.gco:CharacterString: The citation to be used in publications which use this data should follow the format: RAN HYDROGRAPHY AND METOC BRANCH, http://www.metoc.gov.au accessed at dd-MMM-YYYY

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: This data was gathered from ship launched Expendable Bathythermogaph (XBT) probes. The XBT probe is dropped off a moving ship and falls under its own weight. The probe has a a thermistor in its nose whose electrical resistance changes as the water temperature changes. This is sensed as a changing resistance which is transmitted to the digital recorder on the ship. Using an algorithm the resistance is converted to a water temperature. The speed of fall of the probe is known and from the elapsed time the depth is calculated. The time of the XBT drop is recorded from the computers clock. The position of the drop is obtained from the ship's satellite navigation or GPS. Position is manually entered by the ship's operator.

mcp:name.gco:CharacterString: temperature of the water column by expendable bathythermograph (XBT)

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
The RAN METOC use standard UNESCO, IOC/IODE documented procedures for quality control of temperature profile data. Temperature data undergoes scientific quality control procedures. Each temperature profile is visually inspected for possible faults and checked for profile-to-profile consistency with nearest neighbours and also compared with climatological average temperature profiles from the World Ocean Atlas. Temperature/depth pairs are flagged with quality control flags which are stored with the data.
Starting in 2009 the RAN METOC XBT data was quality controlled using the CSIRO developed MQUEST system. MQUEST is a Matlab-based system for quality evaluation of subsurface temperature profile data (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/Mquest/MQuESTmanual.pdf ). Prior to 2009 RAN METOC used the 'Marine QC' Ver3.0 a semi-automatic system, developed by RAN-METOC, for the quality control.
The meaning of quality control flags are documented in Table 1 of CSIRO Marine Laboratories Report No. 221 (1994) titled "Quality Control Cookbook for XBT data" (see http://www.marine.csiro.au/~gronell/cookbook/csiro.htm ). The flags correspond to a set of 'data quality classes' (0-9) which have the same meaning as in Section 2 of IOC Manuals and guides No. 22 GTSPP REAL-TIME QUALITY CONTROL MANUAL (see http://www.meds-sdmm.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/alphapro/gtspp/qcmans/mg22/guide22_e.htm ).
After QC has completed the data is output from MQUEST system into MEDS-ASCII GTSPP file format see http://www.nodc.noaa.gov/GTSPP/document/datafmt/medsfmt.html for details about this data format.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: IMOS - ANMN New South Wales (NSW) Port Kembla Offshore Wave Data (WAVEPOK) - Deployment No. 2 25-OCT-1976 to 16-NOV-1983

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains ocean wave data from a wave monitoring buoy moored off Port Kembla at latitude -34.451111, longitude 150.996389 and water depth 50 metres. The data is gathered by the Waverider system developed by the Dutch company, Datawell. The Waverider system uses an accelerometer mounted in a loose tethered buoy (0.7 or 0.9m in diameter) to measure the vertical accelerations of the buoy as it moves with the water surface. The accelerations are integrated twice within the buoy and the displacement signal so obtained is then transmitted to a shore station where it is processed to provide wave data statistics. The wave data is stored on the receiving station PC before routine transfer to Manly Hydraulics Laboratory via email.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Data collection funded by NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (OEH)
Waverider buoy system and data management undertaken for OEH by NSW Public Works Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). IMOS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)
Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN). AODN is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS) and the Super Science Initiative (SSI)

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Manly Hydraulics Laboratory

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: 110B King Street, Manly Vale
